the former needs a design meeting, the later doesn't

simulacrum said:

it's just one of the cases where MCP process didn't work out well in practice, though I don't think we have a process that would've other than just 'some folks meet and make a decision'

I kind of think this is what happened, but we should probably have been more explicit that this is the plan
I kind of like the new names though :)

I like them too, although I think I would prefer lib for libraries, src for compiler, and util for support things like bootstrap. Or, if we didn't want to move so much stuff around, lib, comp, and src.
comp is not at all clear, I'd rather have rustc
Agreed. lib as an abbreviation for library is extremely common. comp isn't obviously compiler; rustc seems preferable there.

Conceptually, library and compiler are the most intuitive to me but annoying to type. std and rustc are much nicer to type and I think reasonably obvious to a Rust user but then you have the unfortunate std/std and rustc/rustc naming...

Perhaps those could become std/lib and rustc/bin? Maybe that's trying too hard lol
I think I'd find lib/std more intuitive.
Yeah, that makes more sense as it holds all the libraries we ship in the distribution not just std.
I've been hitting this really often when I try to type a path lately, but I'm pretty sure it's "newness" effect so far
I do think renaming the directories now that we've split things apart is much easier and we have prior art, but I think it may make sense to wait a bit -- sort of see how this works out
I like rustc/bin
one of my complaints with the default cargo setup is too much nesting :P
In what contexts do you have to type these paths?
x.py doc library/std in the shell
For me it usually happens in shell (which has autocomplete), or vscode search (which is fuzzy), so the length is not an issue in both cases.
oh, it's not a length thing
it's literally "I type src/libstd, get confused"
I've been training myself to use fuzzy search instead though which mostly solves this
